ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments:
I learned to write better! Michael was an excellent professor and really helped me sharpen my writing skills. 
In class we learned a lot of history and philosophy mainly on Derridas concept of hauntology. We also ready essays on the belief of ghosts as our section is called the anatomy of ghosts.

I learned about Hauntologies which is really fascinating if youre into ghosts. I learned that things are not always what they are perceived to be and that there is a lot of room for interpretation and risk when writing! It taught me how to write a college paper in a fun and new way.
I developed insight on how to write a college-appropriate paper analyzing intricate texts and ideas. I also learned how to do a close-reading of pictures and texts.

This class was an amazing introductory writing course that both provided insight into writing college level papers as well as exploring interesting higher level concepts like hauntology. These higher level connections made the class engaging and meaningful, connecting interesting readings to students own ideological perspectives.

I experienced my first insight into college writing and as such, I learned how to write concisely and efficiently to an academic audience. I also learned much about hauntology and the different ghosts of society.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
Michael really helped my write better so that was a strength. I also learned how to annotate better and from a complex argument. Class was taught well. 
Weaknesses sometimes Michael cancelled office hours and he is slow at replying to emails. This semester might have been an anomaly though.

This course was strong in interesting reads with a professor willing to dissect these texts. The professor was also engaged in helping the students along the path of this class. Some papers were more helpful than others, and this was discussed in our final class period.

This course is incredibly well structured, with a clear connection between assigned readings and assignments given. Each reading builds off the previous, and class discussions dissect each reading to provide various interpretations and dialogues.

This course had a strong approach to teaching writing in academia, especially with the different types of writing that were assigned. I also enjoyed the various discussions we had about the unique topic of ghosts, especially the complexity and depth that we covered. However, I would have moved some of the readings in order to introduce certain topics first.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes if you want to write better and have a broader concept of history and philosophy.
Yes, if you enjoy learning about politics and historical accounts regarding things that haunt from the past.
Yes! English 114 is an amazing class to dig into writing; the subject on ghosts was just an added bonus because of how interesting it was! This course is instrumental in one's time at Yale.

I would and have recommended this course to other students, it offers a unique conceptual interpretation of history and the concept of ghosts, ideologically pushing students to consider and create new shared perspectives.

I would definitely recommend this course to another student as an introduction to writing for academia. This course covered that requirement as well as presented an incredibly interesting topic for that purpose.
